items.question: The revisionist interpretation of the Glorious Revolution emphasizes:
options: B) Continuity with existing constitutional arrangements and accidental outcomes

items.question: Christopher Hill's "Century of Revolution" thesis is challenged by revisionists who argue:
options: B) Social and economic continuities outweighed political changes

items.question: The "fiscal-military state" thesis (Brewer) argues British success stemmed from:
options: B) Efficient taxation and credit systems enabling sustained warfare

items.question: E.P. Thompson's "Making of the English Working Class" revolutionized historiography by:
options: B) Emphasizing cultural formation and agency of working people

items.question: The "Whig interpretation of history" has been criticized for:
options: B) Teleological assumptions and presentist bias

items.question: Post-colonial historians' critique of British imperialism challenges:
options: B) Civilizing mission narratives and cultural imperialism

items.question: The "gentlemanly capitalism" thesis (Cain and Hopkins) argues:
options: B) Financial and service sector interests shaped imperial policy

items.question: Gender historians' reinterpretation of Victorian "separate spheres" reveals:
options: B) Complex negotiations and women's hidden influences

items.question: The "British decline" debate's competing explanations include all EXCEPT:
options: A) Cultural factors and anti-industrial bias
B) Natural and inevitable process requiring no explanation

items.question: New Imperial History's contribution emphasizes:
options: B) Mutual constitution of metropole and colony

items.question: The evolution from "mixed constitution" to parliamentary sovereignty involved:
options: B) Gradual shifts through precedent, crisis, and reinterpretation

items.question: The concept of "virtual representation" defended pre-1832 arrangements by claiming:
options: B) MPs represented interests not individuals

items.question: The relationship between financial revolution and political stability after 1688:
options: B) National debt created stakeholders in regime stability

items.question: Burke's defense of the unreformed constitution rested on:
options: B) Organic development and accumulated wisdom

items.question: The Crown's political neutrality emerged through:
options: B) Series of precedents and political pressures from George III to Victoria

items.question: The concept of "elective dictatorship" (Hailsham) critiques:
options: B) Excessive executive power through Commons control

items.question: Constitutional conventions' binding force derives from:
options: B) Political consequences and precedent weight

items.question: The West Lothian Question reveals tensions between:
options: B) Territorial and union-wide representation principles

items.question: Parliamentary sovereignty's compatibility with EU membership involved:
options: B) Theoretical supremacy versus practical constraints

items.question: The Human Rights Act's constitutional significance lies in:
options: B) Incorporating ECHR while maintaining parliamentary sovereignty

items.question: The "Great Divergence" debate about British industrialization emphasizes:
options: B) Contingent factors including coal, colonies, and institutions

items.question: Proto-industrialization thesis suggests Industrial Revolution was:
options: B) Culmination of gradual rural manufacturing growth

items.question: The relationship between slavery and industrialization remains contested regarding:
options: B) Capital accumulation, markets, and raw material supply

items.question: "Gentlemanly capitalism" affected British economic development by:
options: B) Prioritizing finance and empire over domestic manufacturing

items.question: The "climacteric" of the 1870s represented:
options: B) Structural shift from industrial leadership to relative decline

items.question: British economic policy's "Treasury view" constrained responses to depression by:
options: B) Orthodox commitment to balanced budgets and gold standard

items.question: The "stop-go" cycle of post-war economic management reflected:
options: B) Conflicts between growth, employment, and sterling stability

items.question: Financialization's impact on British economy includes:
options: B) Sectoral imbalance and regional inequality

items.question: The "Dutch disease" from North Sea oil manifested as:
options: B) Currency appreciation damaging manufacturing exports

items.question: Brexit's economic rationale conflicted between:
options: B) Sovereignty gains versus market access losses

items.question: The "official mind" of imperialism (Robinson and Gallagher) operated through:
options: B) Reactive responses to local crises and rivalries

items.question: "Informal empire" through free trade differed from formal empire by:
options: B) Achieving dominance without direct political control

items.question: The "collaborator thesis" explains imperial control through:
options: B) Local elite cooperation and mutual benefits

items.question: Imperial federation failed because:
options: B) Conflicting dominion nationalism and British reluctance to share power

items.question: The economic balance sheet of empire remains contested regarding:
options: B) Distribution of costs/benefits across classes and time

items.question: Cultural imperialism operated through:
options: B) Education, language, and value systems creating hegemony

items.question: The "Anglosphere" concept's modern relevance reflects:
options: B) Shared institutions and strategic alignment

items.question: Decolonization's "transfer of power" interpretation obscures:
options: B) Continued economic dependence and neo-colonial relationships

items.question: The Commonwealth's evolution from Empire demonstrates:
options: B) Adaptation to post-colonial realities while maintaining connections

items.question: Post-imperial Britain's identity crisis manifests in:
options: B) Tensions between European, Atlantic, and global orientations

items.question: British "way of warfare" traditionally emphasized:
options: B) Naval power, limited liability, and coalition building

items.question: The "balance of power" principle in British foreign policy meant:
options: B) Preventing any single power dominating Europe

items.question: Appeasement's intellectual foundations included:
options: B) Versailles guilt, strategic overstretch, and anti-communism

items.question: The "special relationship" mythology obscures:
options: B) Asymmetric dependence and divergent interests

items.question: Suez's significance transcended military defeat to represent:
options: B) Imperial overreach and subordination to superpowers

items.question: Nuclear deterrence strategy reflected:
options: B) Compensation for conventional weakness and status anxiety

items.question: European integration presented Britain with dilemmas between:
options: B) Sovereignty, economic benefits, and strategic positioning

items.question: The Falklands War's deeper significance involved:
options: B) Post-imperial identity and domestic political realignment

items.question: Blair's "doctrine of international community" represented:
options: B) Liberal interventionism challenging Westphalian principles

items.question: Post-Cold War strategic confusion reflects:
options: B) Absence of defining enemy and multiple competing priorities

items.question: The "labour aristocracy" thesis explains reformism through:
options: B) Skilled workers' privileged position dampening radicalism

items.question: Victorian "respectability" functioned as:
options: B) Complex class marker and social control mechanism

items.question: The "strange death of Liberal England" thesis attributes decline to:
options: B) Pre-war crises revealing fundamental social tensions

items.question: Welfare state origins debate between Whig and social control interpretations:
options: B) Contests whether reform represented progress or elite stabilization

items.question: The "permissive society" represented:
options: B) Complex renegotiation of authority, individualism, and values

items.question: Working-class conservatism challenges simple class-politics correlation through:
options: B) Cultural values, nationalism, and pragmatic calculations

items.question: The "underclass" debate's political significance involves:
options: B) Contested explanations between structural and cultural factors

items.question: Multiculturalism's critics and defenders disagree on:
options: B) Integration models and national identity definitions

items.question: The "New Right" synthesis combined:
options: B) Neo-liberal economics with traditional conservative values

items.question: Post-industrial society thesis implications include:
options: B) Class restructuring and new political alignments

items.question: The "invention of tradition" (Hobsbawm) reveals:
options: B) Modern construction of supposedly timeless practices

items.question: British empiricism's influence on political culture emphasized:
options: B) Pragmatism, precedent, and suspicion of ideology

items.question: The "cultural turn" in British historiography shifted focus from:
options: B) Social structures to meanings and representations

items.question: "Britishness" as constructed identity emerged from:
options: B) Political project uniting diverse kingdoms against others

items.question: The "public sphere" concept (Habermas) applied to Britain shows:
options: B) Bourgeois exclusions and gradual expansion

items.question: Victorian "crisis of faith" reflected:
options: B) Complex negotiations between science, religion, and morality

items.question: The "linguistic turn" impacts understanding of political discourse by:
options: B) Analyzing how language shapes political possibilities

items.question: British anti-intellectualism manifests in:
options: B) Preference for "common sense" over theoretical systems

items.question: The "heritage industry" critique suggests:
options: B) Commodified nostalgia replacing critical engagement

items.question: Post-modern challenges to national narrative include:
options: B) Multiple perspectives and questioning master narratives

items.question: The "internal colonialism" thesis applies to Celtic regions through:
options: B) Economic exploitation and cultural subordination

items.question: Scottish Enlightenment's relationship to Union demonstrates:
options: B) How union enabled distinctive intellectual flowering

items.question: The "North-South divide" reflects:
options: B) Historical industrial patterns and policy biases

items.question: Welsh nationalism's different trajectory from Scottish reflects:
options: B) Language focus and industrial integration patterns

items.question: Ulster Unionism's complexity involves:
options: B) Settler colonialism, religious identity, and conditional loyalty

items.question: London's dominance creates tensions through:
options: B) Economic concentration and political-cultural hegemony

items.question: The "Celtic fringe" concept problematically:
options: B) Implies marginality and homogenizes diverse regions

items.question: Regional devolution's asymmetry reflects:
options: B) Different national movements and English ambivalence

items.question: The "resentment of the provinces" manifests in:
options: B) Brexit geography and populist appeals

items.question: Post-imperial Britain's territorial future involves:
options: B) Competing scenarios from federal reform to dissolution

items.question: The "history from below" movement's methodological challenges include:
options: B) Source scarcity requiring creative approaches

items.question: Oral history's contribution to British historiography:
options: B) Captures marginalized voices while raising reliability questions

items.question: Quantitative history's limits in British context include:
The "archive turn" reveals:
options: B) Power relations in document creation and preservation

items.question: Digital humanities' impact on British history includes:
options: B) New analytical possibilities and accessibility questions

items.question: Comparative method's application to British history challenges:
Memory studies approach British history through:
options: B) How past is remembered and used politically

items.question: Environmental history reframes British development by:
options: B) Integrating natural constraints and consequences

items.question: Gender analysis transforms understanding by:
options: B) Revealing gendered structures throughout society

items.question: Global history approaches challenge:
options: B) Nation-centered narratives and isolated development

items.question: The "end of history" thesis applies to Britain through:
options: B) Questions about post-Cold War ideological alternatives

items.question: "Liquid modernity" (Bauman) manifests in British society through:
options: B) Institutional flux and identity uncertainty

items.question: The "risk society" thesis illuminates British policy dilemmas in:
options: B) Managing uncertain technological and environmental threats

items.question: Post-truth politics challenges British democratic traditions by:
options: B) Undermining shared factual basis for deliberation

items.question: The "surveillance society" debate in Britain involves:
options: B) Balance between security and privacy in digital age

items.question: Algorithmic governance raises questions about:
options: B) Democratic accountability and human agency

items.question: Climate change politics creates tensions between:
options: B) Economic interests, international obligations, and intergenerational justice

items.question: The "fourth industrial revolution" challenges include:
options: B) Employment disruption and inequality amplification

items.question: British "soft power" in post-Brexit context depends on:
options: B) Cultural influence, institutions, and strategic positioning

items.question: Historical consciousness in contemporary Britain reflects:
options: B) Contested memories and instrumental uses of the past
